instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.SMC_RESET: What is SMC_RESET? SMC_RESET is not a signal, it is an abbreviation for “SMC_RESET_L”, which is the signal someone is referring to when they type “SMC_RESET”  "SMC_RESET_L is a signal that resets the SMC when it is low(this is what the “_L” prefix means), and lets the SMC out of reset mode when it is high. .
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> signal at 0V
threads.message: good day guys , this board is making me go crazy, <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET</SIGNAL> is 0V , but when I remove <RESISTOR>R5110</RESISTOR> it goes high , when I put it back its low, I replaced it, but no difference , I tried with the SMC as well as <RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR> to rule out a faulty <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, and even <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR> replaced , all with no changes , please where do I go from here ? also the jtag is already removed even though was Spotless

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> signal at 0V
threads.message: probably pulled down by the SMC then..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> signal at 0V
threads.message:
Post all voltages for <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>.
Change <CAPACITOR>C5101</CAPACITOR>.
Don't forget to disconnect trackpad flex.
If still the same, remove <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> and check if <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> goes high.

threads.message:

probably pulled down by the SMC then..

have replaced 3 functional SMC, with <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> removed it goes high

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> signal at 0V
threads.message:
I have replaced <CAPACITOR>C5101</CAPACITOR> but no changes , with <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> removed  <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is high 
 below are the readings of <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>

<CHIP>U5110</CHIP>

PIN 1. 3.40V

PIN 2.GND

PIN 3.0V

PIN 4.0V

PIN 5. 0V

PIN 6.3V

PIN 7.3.3V

PIN 8. 1.1 and drops gradually

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> signal at 0V
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> signal at 0V
threads.message: my bad , <RESISTOR>R5127</RESISTOR> voltage is resent and pin 3 is 3.3V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> signal at 0V
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> signal at 0V
threads.message:
Thank you , the post can be closed .
The issue was as you pointed out at <RESISTOR>R5127</RESISTOR>, even though 3.3V was present in and out , there was a break between the resistor and pin 3 of <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>, I recreated the break and the board worked okay . Thank you so much
